1112523827047616512.text: I'm more bullish than ever on on-chain governance and think this will be one of the greatest advantages of Cosmos. There will not be ambiguity about what the community will want and the network will be able to resolve conflict much more quickly and efficiently.

1112523826510729217.text: Both sides claimed that the users were on their side, but there was no way of measuring it. Even if you just consider the value of the time spent on this debate, I'd venture that it easily cost >$10M probably much more. Now Ethereum seems to have its own mini-version of this.

1112523825944518656.text: I was fairly deeply involved in the Bitcoin blocksize debate. For those who don't remember, it lasted several years and was extremely toxic. It drove many out of the community. It ended up causing the split into BTC and BCH. And nobody ever knew what the Bitcoin community wanted.

1112523825437007872.text: Cosmos has been live just over two weeks, but already we had two on-chain proposals. Both initiated by different validators. The participation has been extremely high with 74% and 81% of voting power participating (https://hubble.figment.network/chains/cosmoshub-1/governance/proposals/1 …).

1112523824522649600.text: The ability for delegators to participate is very important so we built a tool on the @ChorusOne website that allows delegators to vote directly. Soon, I expect that delegators will also choose validators based on their political views and how they participate in governance.

1112523823985778688.text: In Cosmos normal delegators have the ability to diverge from their validator's vote. They can see what the validator votes, but if they don't like it they can overwrite it for their own tokens. I expect that this will become widely used for some votes in the future.

1112523823385993217.text: Tezos does this too, but there is a major difference between the two. Only bakers can vote there. This is problematic. The interest of bakers/validators can easily diverge from token holders. Token holders can easily be disenfranchised. (I realize that Tezos may change this.)

1112523822853324800.text: Validators are deeply engaged with the network. So you can expect that they will be informed and participate in the vast majority of governance decisions. By having as the default that all votes get inherited by validators, you guarantee very high participation.

1112523822316441601.text: In the last years, when people would discuss projects working on on-chain governance, @cosmos was rarely mentioned. But I have always thought that the Cosmos governance model is simple, but brilliant.
